intro: Chamaerhodos grandiflora var. albiflora, commonly known as white flameflower, is a striking perennial plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Lythraceae family and is characterized by its showy, white to pale pink flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant features broad, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, giving it a soft, velvety texture. It thrives in moist, well-drained soil and partial to full sun, making it a popular choice for wetland gardens. Its unique floral display and adaptability to wet environments make it a valuable addition to native plant landscapes.
